{{Use South African English|date=November 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Trevor Noah | image = Trevor Noah 2017.jpg | alt = | caption = Noah in 2017 | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1984|2|20}} | birth_place = [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|1984|2|20}} --> | death_place = | other_names = | active = 2002–present | medium = {{hlist|Stand-up|television|film|books}} | genre = {{hlist|[[Political satire|Political]]/[[news satire]]|[[observational comedy]]|[[surreal humor]]|[[black comedy]]|[[insult comedy]]|[[deadpan]]}} | subject = {{hlist|[[Mass media]]/[[news media]]/[[media studies|media criticism]]|[[politics of the United States|American politics]]|[[Culture of South Africa|South African culture]]|[[current events]]|[[race relations]]|[[popular culture|pop culture]]}} | website = {{URL|www.trevornoah.com}} | signature = Trevor_Noah_signature.svg }}
'''Trevor Noah''' (born 20 February 1984) is a [[South African]] comedian, political commentator, actor, and television host.<ref name="thedailybeast1">{{cite web |author=Jesse Lichtenstein |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2012/06/17/can-trevor-noah-s-comedy-jump-from-south-africa-to-the-u-s.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120618205145/http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2012/06/17/can-trevor-noah-s-comedy-jump-from-south-africa-to-the-u-s.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=18 June 2012 |title=Can Trevor Noah's comedy jump from South Africa to the U.S.? |work=[[The Daily Beast]] |date=18 June 2012 |accessdate=4 November 2012 }}</ref> He is known for hosting ''[[The Daily Show]]'', an American [[news satire|satirical news program]] on [[Comedy Central]].
Born in [[Johannesburg]], Noah began his career as a comedian, presenter, and actor in his native South Africa in 2002. He held several television hosting roles with the [[South African Broadcasting Corporation]] (SABC), and was the runner-up in their fourth season of ''[[Strictly Come Dancing (South African TV series)|Strictly Come Dancing]]'' in 2008.<ref name="tvsa"/> From 2010 to 2011, Noah was the creator and host of ''Tonight with Trevor Noah'' on [[M-Net]] and [[DStv]].<ref name="mnet"/> His stand-up comedy career attained international success, leading to appearances on American [[late-night talk show]]s and British [[panel show]]s. In 2014, Noah became the [[List of The Daily Show correspondents|Senior International Correspondent for ''The Daily Show'']], and the following year, he succeeded long-time host [[Jon Stewart]] and is set to remain in this position up until 2022.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-14/-daily-show-host-noah-lands-new-deal-as-trump-bits-lift-ratings|title=‘The Daily Show’ Host Trevor Noah Lands New Deal After Ratings Success|work=Bloomberg|last=Shaw|first=Lucas|date=15 September 2017|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref>
Noah's autobiographical comedy book ''[[Born a Crime]]'' was published in 2016 and garnered critical acclaim.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news |last=Kakutani |first=Michiko |authorlink=Michiko Kakutani |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/28/books/review-born-a-crime-trevor-noahs-raw-account-of-life-under-apartheid.html |title='Born a Crime,' Trevor Noah's Raw Account of Life Under Apartheid |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2016-11-28 |accessdate=2017-03-18 }}</ref><ref name="LARB">{{cite news |last=Darden |first=Jeneé |url=https://lareviewofbooks.org/article/born-crime-memoir-love-hope-resistance/ |title=Born a Crime: A Memoir of Love, Hope, and Resistance |work=[[Los Angeles Review of Books]] |publisher=Los Angeles Review of Books |date=2017-02-18 |accessdate=2017-03-18 }}</ref><ref name="USATODAY">{{cite news |last=Seymour |first=Gene |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/books/2016/11/14/born-a-crime-trevor-noah-book-review/93600572/ |title=Trevor Noah recalls childhood under apartheid in new memoir |work=[[USAToday]] |publisher=[[Gannett Company]] |date=2016-11-14 |accessdate=2017-03-18 }}</ref><ref name="Penguin"/> Noah was named one of "The 35 Most Powerful People in New York Media" by ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' in 2017 and 2018.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/35-powerful-people-new-york-media-993285|title=The 35 Most Powerful People in New York Media|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=April 13, 2017|access-date=December 6, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420011814/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/35-powerful-people-new-york-media-993285|archivedate=20 April 2013|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/35-powerful-nyc-media-figures-2018-hosts-anchors-more-1100942|title=The 35 Most Powerful People in New York Media|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=April 12, 2018|access-date=June 20, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420011814/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/35-powerful-nyc-media-figures-2018-hosts-anchors-more-1100942|archivedate=20 April 2013|df=}}</ref> In 2018, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine named him [[Time 100|one of the 100 most influential people in the world]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/collection/most-influential-people-2018/5217611/trevor-noah/|title=Trevor Noah|work=Time|date=April 19, 2018|accessdate=April 19, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180420020720/http://time.com/collection/most-influential-people-2018/5217611/trevor-noah/|archivedate=20 April 2018|df=}}</ref>
==Early life== Trevor Noah was born on 20 February 1984 in [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2015/03/31/new-daily-show-host-tweeted-a-fat-chick-joke-at-age-27/|title=New 'Daily Show' host tweeted a 'fat-chick joke' at age 27!|last1=Wemple|first1=Erik|date=31 March 2015|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=11 April 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZFLnASRU?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2015/03/31/new-daily-show-host-tweeted-a-fat-chick-joke-at-age-27/|archivedate=13 June 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nation.co.ke/lifestyle/weekend/Trevor-Noah-The-making-of-a-global-star-from-Mama-Boy/1220-3907478-q73aj4/index.html|title=Trevor Noah: The making of a global star from Mama’s Boy|last=Odhiambo|first=Tom|date=28 April 2017|work=Daily Nation|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en-UK}}</ref> His father Robert is of [[Swiss people|Swiss German]] ancestry, and his mother, Patricia Nombuyiselo Noah,<!--Her full name (as it appears in legal documents) is Patricia Nombuyiselo Noah. News and Media refer to her as both "Patricia Noah" or "Nombuyiselo Noah" or her full name. The rest of this article will use "Nombuyiselo Noah."--> is of [[Xhosa people|Xhosa]] ancestry. She [[Conversion to Judaism|converted to Judaism]] when he was 10 or 11 years old,<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=503009220 |title=Trevor Noah Says He Grew Up 'In The Shadow Of A Giant' (His Mom) |first=Terry |last=Gross |publisher=NPR |date=2016-11-22|accessdate=2017-01-18}}</ref> but did not have him convert, although she introduced him to some aspects and practices of Judaism.<ref name=":0" />
Under [[apartheid]] legislation, Noah's mother was classified as [[Bantu peoples in South Africa|Black]], and his father was classified as [[White South African|White]]. His parents' interracial relationship was illegal at the time of his birth under apartheid law. Interracial sexual relations and marriages were not legalised until the [[Immorality and Prohibition of Mixed Marriages Amendment Act, 1985|amended Immorality Act of 1985]], a year after Noah's birth. Patricia Noah was jailed and fined by the South African government.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Noah|first1=Trevor|title=Summary of Born a Crime: Stories from a South African Childhood by Trevor Noah|date=1 August 2017 |publisher=BookHabits |isbn=978-1-537-86707-6|url=https://books.google.com.my/books?id=OhcvDwAAQBAJ&pg=PP10&dq=trevor+noah+born+1984#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://allthingscomedy.com/contents/1851/17-ep-55---interview-with-south-african-comedian-trevor-noah-podcast |title=Ep. 55 – interview with South African comedian Trevor Noah |publisher= |accessdate=30 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402171134/http://allthingscomedy.com/contents/1851/17-ep-55---interview-with-south-african-comedian-trevor-noah-podcast |archivedate=2 April 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> She and her mother, Nomalizo Frances Noah, raised Trevor.<ref>{{cite news |title=Trevor Noah’s tough upbringing in Soweto will help him: granny |url=http://www.thenewage.co.za/155558-1007-53-Trevor_Noahs_tough_upbringing_in_Soweto_will_help_himgranny|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407183359/http://www.thenewage.co.za/155558-1007-53-Trevor_Noahs_tough_upbringing_in_Soweto_will_help_himgranny|dead-url=yes |archive-date=7 April 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2015|work=[[The New Age (South African newspaper)|The New Age]]|date=2 April 2015}}</ref> Noah spent his early youth at the private Maryvale College (at the age of three he started pre school, at the age of five he went to primary school), a Catholic school in Johannesburg.<ref name="nytimes33114">{{cite news|authorlink=Dave Itzkoff|last1=Itzkoff|first1=Dave|title=Trevor Noah to Succeed Jon Stewart on ‘The Daily Show’|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/31/arts/television/trevor-noah-to-succeed-jon-stewart-on-the-daily-show.html?_r=1|accessdate=11 April 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=30 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="Armstrong">{{cite news |author=Stephen Armstrong |title=Heard the one about the Swiss South African? |publisher=''[[Sunday Times]]'' ''Culture'' magazine |date=16 December 2012 |pages=12–13 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghampost.co.uk/whats-on/comedy-gigs/south-african-comedian-trevor-noah-6319931|title=South African comedian Trevor Noah to play Birmingham’s Glee Club|author=Roz Laws|date=22 November 2013|work=birminghampost|accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref> During his childhood, he attended [[Roman Catholic]] church every Sunday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3023806/How-stepfather-new-Daily-host-Trevor-Noah-tried-hunt-kill-shooting-mother-leaving-dead-South-African-slum-comedian-raised.html|title=Daily Show host Trevor Noah's stepfather tried to hunt and kill him|work=Mail Online}}</ref>
== Career == In 2002, aged eighteen, Noah had a bit role on an episode of the South African [[soap opera]] ''[[Isidingo]]''. He then began hosting his own radio show ''Noah's Ark'' on Gauteng's leading youth radio station, [[YFM]]. Noah dropped his radio show and acting to focus on [[comedy]], and has performed with South African comedians such as: David Kau, [[Kagiso Lediga]], [[Riaad Moosa]], [[Darren Simpson]], [[Marc Lottering]], [[Barry Hilton]], and [[Nik Rabinowitz]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bafunnybafunny.com |title=Bafunny Bafunny official website |publisher= |date= |accessdate=4 November 2012}}</ref> international comedians such as [[Paul Rodriguez (actor)|Paul Rodriguez]], [[Carl Barron]], [[Dan Ilic]], and [[Paul Zerdin]], and as the opening act for [[Gabriel Iglesias]] in November 2007 and Canadian comedian [[Russell Peters]] on his South African tour.
Noah went on to host an educational TV programme, ''Run The Adventure'' (2004–2006) on [[SABC 2]]. In 2007, he hosted ''The Real Goboza'', a gossip-themed show on [[SABC 1]],<ref name="tvsa">{{cite web |url=http://www.tvsa.co.za/actorprofile.asp?actorID=7105 |title=Trevor Noah – Actor Profile |publisher=Tvsa.co.za |accessdate=4 November 2012 }}</ref> and ''Siyadlala'', a sports show also on the SABC. In 2008, Noah co-hosted, alongside Pabi Moloi, ''The Amazing Date'' (a dating gameshow) and was a ''[[Strictly Come Dancing (South African TV series)|Strictly Come Dancing]]'' contestant in the fourth series. In 2009, he hosted the 3rd Annual [[South Africa Film and Television Awards]] (SAFTAs) and co-hosted alongside Eugene Khoza on ''The Axe Sweet Life'', a reality competition series. In 2010, Noah hosted the sixteenth annual ''[[South African Music Awards]]'' and also hosted ''Tonight with Trevor Noah'' on [[MNet]] (for the second series, it moved to [[DStv]]'s Mzansi Magic Channel).<ref name="mnet">{{cite web|url=http://beta.mnet.co.za/fanclub/?clubId=1744 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100818031645/http://beta.mnet.co.za/fanclub/?clubId=1744 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=18 August 2010 |title=Tonight with Trevor Noah |publisher=Beta.mnet.co.za |date=1 April 2007 |accessdate=4 November 2012 |df= }}</ref> In 2010, Noah also became a spokesperson and [[consumer protection]] agent for [[Cell C]], South Africa's third-largest mobile phone network provider.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cellc.co.za/tell-trevor/topic |title=Tell Trevor — Cell C South Africa |publisher=Cellc.co.za |date= |accessdate=4 November 2012 }}</ref>
Noah has performed all over South Africa in ''The Blacks Only Comedy Show'', the ''Heavyweight Comedy Jam'', the ''[[Vodacom]] Campus Comedy Tour'', the Cape Town International Comedy Festival, the Jozi Comedy Festival, and ''Bafunny Bafunny'' (2010).<ref>{{cite web|title=Bafunny, Bafunny |url=http://www.royalalberthall.com/tickets/bafunny-bafunny/default.aspx |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100205024338/http://www.royalalberthall.com/tickets/bafunny-bafunny/default.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 February 2010 |publisher=[[Royal Albert Hall]] |accessdate=12 October 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Review: Bafunny Bafunny is a Winner |publisher= Whats On In Cape Town|url=http://www.whatsonincapetown.com/post/review-bafunny-bafunny/ |accessdate=12 October 2013 }}</ref> His stand-up comedy specials in South Africa include ''The Daywalker'' (2009), ''Crazy Normal'' (2011), ''That's Racist'' (2012), and ''It's My Culture'' (2013).
In 2011, he relocated to the [[United States]].<ref name="channel24" /> On 6 January 2012, Noah became the first South African stand-up comedian to appear on ''[[The Tonight Show]]''; and, on 17 May 2013, he became the first to appear on ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]''.<ref name="Armstrong" /><ref>{{cite web |author=[[Jay Leno]] |url=http://www.nbc.com/the-tonight-show/episode-guide/2012-01-02/2012-01-06 |title=The Tonight Show with Jay Leno – Episode Guide |publisher=[[NBC]] |date= |accessdate=4 November 2012}}</ref> Noah was the subject of the 2012 documentary ''You Laugh But It's True''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youlaughbutitstrue.com|title=You Laugh But It's True|author=David Paul Meyer|publisher=|accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref> The same year, he starred in the one-man comedy show ''Trevor Noah: The Racist'',<ref>{{cite web | title=''Trevor Noah: The Racist'' – review |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2012/aug/16/trevor-noah-the-racist-review| |work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate = 12 October 2013 }}</ref> which was based on his similarly titled South African special ''That's Racist''. On 12 September, Noah was the [[Roastmaster]] in a ''[[Comedy Central Roast]]'' of South African [[Afrikaans]] singer [[Steve Hofmeyr]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citypress.co.za/entertainment/war-of-words-erupts-after-hofmeyrs-roast-20120915/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121225125143/http://www.citypress.co.za/entertainment/war-of-words-erupts-after-hofmeyrs-roast-20120915/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 December 2012 |title=War of words erupts after Hofmeyr’s roast |date=15 September 2012 |accessdate=2 April 2015 |website=City Press |publisher= |last= |first= |df= }}</ref> In 2013, he performed the comedy special ''Trevor Noah: African American.''<ref>{{cite web|title=Showtime : ''Trevor Noah: African American'' |url=http://www.sho.com/sho/comedy/titles/3379668/trevor-noah-african-american#/index |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130608114542/http://www.sho.com/sho/comedy/titles/3379668/trevor-noah-african-american |dead-url=yes |archive-date=8 June 2013 |accessdate=12 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> On 11 October 2013, he was a guest on [[BBC Two]]'s comedy panel show ''[[QI]]''.<ref>{{cite web |title=''QI'', Series K, Killers |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03d3p60 |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref> On 29 November 2013, he was a panelist on [[Channel 4]] game show ''[[8 Out of 10 Cats]]''<ref>{{cite tweet |author= Chamber's Management |user= ChambersMgt|number= 406437478627672064 |date= 29 November 2013 |title= .@jimmycarr is your hilarious host for 8 Out 10 Cats again tonight with international stand-up star .@Trevornoah as guest panelist. C4, 9pm! |access-date= 12 September 2014 }}</ref> and appeared on [[Sean Lock]]'s team in ''[[8 Out of 10 Cats Does Countdown]]'' on 12 September 2014.
=== ''The Daily Show'' === {{further|The Daily Show}} [[File:Trevor Noah at the Dubai Comedy Festival.jpg|thumb|Noah (second from left) at the 2015 Dubai Comedy Festival]]
In December 2014, Noah became a recurring contributor on ''[[The Daily Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/tv/news/the-daily-show-adds-comedians-hasan-minhaj-and-trevor-noah-1201326740/|title=‘The Daily Show’ Adds Comedians Hasan Minhaj and Trevor Noah|first=Shelli|last=Weinstein|work=Variety|date=10 October 2014|accessdate=19 November 2014}}</ref> On 30 March 2015, [[Comedy Central]] announced that Noah would succeed [[Jon Stewart]] as host of ''The Daily Show''; his tenure began on 28 September 2015.<ref name="nytimes33114" /> Within hours after announced as Stewart's successor, attention was drawn on the Internet to several jokes that Noah had posted on his [[Twitter]] account, which were criticised by some as being offensive to women and [[Jews]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Itzkoff|first=Dave|title=Trevor Noah, New ‘Daily Show’ Host, Comes Under Scrutiny for Tweets|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/01/arts/television/trevor-noah-new-daily-show-host-comes-under-scrutiny-for-tweets.html?smid=tw-nytmedia&seid=auto|accessdate=31 March 2015|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=31 March 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420011814/https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/01/arts/television/trevor-noah-new-daily-show-host-comes-under-scrutiny-for-tweets.html?smid=tw-nytmedia&seid=auto|archivedate=31 March 2015|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/641377/new-daily-show-host-trevor-noah-faces-backlash-over-controversial-tweets|title=New Daily Show Host Trevor Noah Faces Backlash Over Controversial Tweets|work=E! Online|date=31 March 2015|accessdate=31 March 2015|first=Francesca|last=Bacrdi|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420011814/http://www.eonline.com/news/641377/new-daily-show-host-trevor-noah-faces-backlash-over-controversial-tweets|archivedate=31 March 2015|df=}}</ref> and to be making fun of the [[Holocaust]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2015/mar/31/trevor-noah-backlash-highlights-jokes-jews-women|title=Daily Show's Trevor Noah under fire for Twitter jokes about Jews and women|first=Lauren|last=Gambino|date=31 March 2015|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017|via=The Guardian|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420011814/https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2015/mar/31/trevor-noah-backlash-highlights-jokes-jews-women|archivedate=31 March 2015|df=}}</ref> Noah responded by tweeting, "To reduce my views to a handful of jokes that didn't land is not a true reflection of my character, nor my evolution as a comedian."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ibtimes.com/trevor-noah-issues-non-apology-offensive-jewish-jokes-slams-critics-1865708|title=Trevor Noah Issues Non Apology For Offensive Jewish Jokes, Slams Critics|first=Maria|last=Vultaggio|date=31 March 2015|publisher=''[[International Business Times]]''|accessdate=1 April 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420011814/https://www.ibtimes.com/trevor-noah-issues-non-apology-offensive-jewish-jokes-slams-critics-1865708|archivedate=1 April 2015|df=}}</ref> [[Comedy Central]] stood behind Noah, saying in a statement, "Like many comedians, Trevor Noah pushes boundaries; he is provocative and spares no one, himself included... To judge him or his comedy based on a handful of jokes is unfair. Trevor is a talented comedian with a bright future at Comedy Central."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/01/arts/television/trevor-noah-new-daily-show-host-comes-under-scrutiny-for-tweets.html?_r=0 |title=Comedy Central Stands Behind Trevor Noah, New ‘Daily Show’ Host, Amid Scrutiny |work=The New York Times|date=31 March 2015 |accessdate=1 April 2015 |deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420011814/https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/01/arts/television/trevor-noah-new-daily-show-host-comes-under-scrutiny-for-tweets.html?_r=0 |archivedate=31 March 2015|df=}}</ref> Mary Kluk, chairperson of the South African Jewish Board of Deputies (SAJBD), said that the jokes were not signs of anti-Jewish prejudice and that they were part of Noah's style of comedy.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pillay|first1=Taschica|title=Trevor Noah's 'playful' jokes don't offend us – SA Jews|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/entertainment/celebrity/2015/04/06/trevor-noah-s-playful-jokes-don-t-offend-us---sa-jews|website=Times Live|accessdate=7 April 2015|date=6 April 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420011814/http://www.timeslive.co.za/entertainment/celebrity/2015/04/06/trevor-noah-s-playful-jokes-don-t-offend-us---sa-jews |archivedate=7 April 2015|df=}}</ref> Noah’s debut received positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the_daily_show_with_trevor_noah/s01 |title=The Daily Show with Trevor Noah (2015–) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817101856/http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the_daily_show_with_trevor_noah/s01 |archivedate=17 August 2015|accessdate=November 5, 2017}}</ref> [[James Poniewozik]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' praised Noah and the shows writers saying, "Mr. Noah's debut was largely successful, it was also because of the operating system - the show's writing - running under the surface".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/30/arts/television/trevor-noah-daily-show-debut.html |title=Review: Trevor Noah Keeps ‘Daily Show’ DNA in Debut |work=The New York Times |date=September 29, 2015 |first=James |last=Poniewozik |accessdate=November 5, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150605072139/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/30/arts/television/trevor-noah-daily-show-debut.html |archivedate=5 June 2015 }}</ref> Robert Lloyd of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' described Noah as "Charming and composed - almost inevitably low-key compared with the habitually antic and astonished Stewart."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-trevor-noah-daily-show-review-20150928-htmlstory.html |title=Review Comfortable, confident Trevor Noah takes over as host of 'The Daily Show' ... and survives |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=September 28, 2015 |first=Robert |last=Lloyd |accessdate=November 5, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013050419/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-trevor-noah-daily-show-review-20150928-htmlstory.html |archivedate=13 October 2014 }}</ref> Noah’s success on the show has led to two stand-up specials on Comedy Central and [[Netflix]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/11/03/daily-show-trevor-noah-comedy-central-stand-up-special|title=Daily Show host Trevor Noah getting Comedy Central stand-up special – EW.com|work=Entertainment Weekly's EW.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/trevor-noah-comedy-special-afraid-dark-set-netflix-968156 |title=Netflix Sets Trevor Noah Comedy Special 'Afraid of the Dark' |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=January 24, 2017 |first=Bryn Elise |last=Sandberg |accessdate=November 5, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013050419/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/trevor-noah-comedy-special-afraid-dark-set-netflix-968156 |archivedate=13 October 2014 }}</ref> On September 14, 2017, it was announced that Comedy Central had extended Noah's contract as host of ''The Daily Show'' for five years, through 2022. He will also produce and host annual end-of-year specials for Comedy Central.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/14/arts/television/trevor-noah-comedy-central-contract.html|title=Trevor Noah Extends Comedy Central Contract Through 2022|last=Itzkoff|first=Dave|date=2017-09-14|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=2017-09-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
In April 2017, it was announced that Noah was developing a talk-show for [[Jordan Klepper]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/04/arts/television/jordan-klepper-the-daily-show-comedy-central-program-of-his-own.html|title=Jordan Klepper of ‘The Daily Show’ Is Getting His Own Show|work=[[The New York Times]]|first=Dave|last=Itzkoff|date=April 4, 2017|accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> On July 2017, the show’s title was revealed to be ''[[The Opposition with Jordan Klepper]]'' and premiered on September 25, 2017.<ref name="premiere">{{cite news|last1=Moraes|first1=Lisa de|title='The Daily Show' Spinoff Starring Jordan Klepper Gets Title & Premiere Date on Comedy Central – TCA|url=https://deadline.com/2017/07/jordan-klepper-the-opposition-september-25-debut-tca-1202135401/|accessdate=July 26, 2017|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=July 25, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420011814/https://deadline.com/2017/07/jordan-klepper-the-opposition-september-25-debut-tca-1202135401/|archivedate=July 26, 2017|df=}}</ref> On June 15, 2018, Comedy Central announced that it was canceling the show after one season, but that Klepper would be hosting a new primetime weekly talk show, ''Klepper''.<ref name="cancellation">{{Cite web| url= https://www.thewrap.com/jordan-klepper-opposition-canceled-new-comedy-central-series-ordered/|title=Comedy Central Cancels ‘The Opposition’ – But Orders New Jordan Klepper Series|first=Tony|last=Maglio|work=[[The Wrap]]|date=June 15, 2018|accessdate= June 15, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420011814/https://www.thewrap.com/jordan-klepper-opposition-canceled-new-comedy-central-series-ordered/|archivedate=June 15, 2018|df=}}</ref>
On February 2018, it was announced that Noah will be executive producing a show with [[Roy Wood Jr.]] titled ''Re-Established''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Petski|first=Denise|url= http://deadline.com/2018/02/trevor-noah-parole-officer-re-established-roy-wood-jr-aaron-mcgruder-1202286654/|title=Roy Wood Jr. To Star In Parole Officer Comedy From Trevor Noah & Aaron McGruder In Works At Comedy Central|date=12 February 2018|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref> In March 2018, Noah signed a multiyear contract with [[Viacom]] that gives [[First look deal|first-look rights]] to any future projects by Noah, be they television, feature films or shortform video content. In addition to the deal, Noah will also be launching an international production and distribution company called Day Zero Productions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Trevor Noah Inks Film and TV Deal With Viacom (Exclusive)|last=Sandberg |first=Bryn Elise|date=March 26, 2018|work=The Hollywood Reporter|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/trevor-noah-inks-film-tv-deal-viacom-1097048|accessdate=February 15, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150211030036/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/trevor-noah-inks-film-tv-deal-viacom-1097048|archivedate=11 February 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref>
=== ''Born a Crime'' === {{further|Born a Crime}} In January 2016, it was announced that Noah signed a book deal with [[Spiegel & Grau]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Italie|first1=Hillel|title=Trevor Noah writing book of personal essays due in November|url=https://www.apnews.com/4a6b34a181db4e7fad3114141e31dd92|website=Associated Press|date=January 26, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013050419/https://www.apnews.com/4a6b34a181db4e7fad3114141e31dd92|archivedate=13 October 2014}}</ref> His book, ''[[Born a Crime]]'' was published on November 15, 2016 and was received favorably by major U.S. book reviewers.<ref name="NYT"/><ref name="LARB"/><ref name="USATODAY"/> It became a #1 ''New York Times'' Bestseller and was named one of the best books of the year by ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[Newsday]]'', ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'', [[NPR]], and ''[[Booklist]]''.<ref name="Penguin">{{cite web |url=http://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/537515/born-a-crime-by-trevor-noah/9780399588174/ |title=Born a Crime by Trevor Noah |work=[[Penguin Random House]] |publisher=[[Spiegel & Grau]] |accessdate=2017-03-18|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161001232156/http://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/537515/born-a-crime-by-trevor-noah/9780399588174|archivedate=1 October 2016|df=}}</ref> It was announced that a film adaptation based on the book will star [[Lupita Nyong'o]] as Trevor's mother Patricia. She will also serve as the film's co-producer alongside Noah.<ref name="LNBAC">{{Cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2018/02/lupita-nyongo-born-a-crime-trevor-noah-book-1202298166/ |title=Lupita Nyong’o To Star In ‘Born A Crime’ Based On Trevor Noah’s Memoir |first=Amanda|last=N'Duka|date=2018-02-21 |website=Deadline Hollywood |access-date=2018-02-21}}</ref> In February 2018, it was announced that Noah would write a second book.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2018/02/trevor-noah-follow-up-born-a-crime-memoir-bought-spiegel-grau-imprint-1202276582/|title=Trevor Noah’s Follow-Up To ‘Born A Crime’ Memoir Bought By Spiegel & Grau Imprint|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=February 1, 2018|accessdate=February 24, 2018|author=Petski, Denise|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604184341/https://deadline.com/2018/02/trevor-noah-follow-up-born-a-crime-memoir-bought-spiegel-grau-imprint-1202276582/|archivedate=4 June 2016|df=}}</ref> In 2018, Noah and ''The Daily Show'' writing staff will release ''The Donald J. Trump Presidential Twitter Library'', the book will comprise hundreds of Trump tweets, and featuring a foreword by [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning historian [[Jon Meacham]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/600003/the-donald-j-trump-presidential-twitter-library-by-the-daily-show-with-trevor-noah-presents/|title=The Donald J. Trump Presidential Twitter Library by The Daily Show with Trevor Noah |work=Penguin Random House |publisher=Spiegel & Grau |accessdate=2018-05-02|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604184341/https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/600003/the-donald-j-trump-presidential-twitter-library-by-the-daily-show-with-trevor-noah-presents/|archivedate=4 June 2016|df=}}</ref>
== Influences == Noah has said of his comedic influences, "The kings are indisputable. [[Richard Pryor]], [[Bill Cosby|[Bill] Cosby]]; for me personally I didn't know of him before I started comedy but [[Eddie Murphy]] changed my view on the thing and I definitely look up to him as a comedic influence. [[Chris Rock]] in terms of the modern black comedian and [[Dave Chappelle]]. Those are the guys that have laid the foundation and have moved the yardstick for all comedians, not just Black comedians."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.essence.com/2013/06/18/trevor-noah-talks-being-south-african-comedian/ |title=New & Next: Meet South African Comedian Trevor Noah |publisher=[[Essence (magazine)|Essence]] |date=14 June 2013 |accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref> He also cited [[Jon Stewart]] as an influence and a mentor, following his appointment to succeed Stewart as host of ''The Daily Show''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/mar/30/trevor-noah-jon-stewart-daily-show-host |title=Trevor Noah to succeed Jon Stewart as host of The Daily Show |publisher=The Guardian |date=30 March 2015 |accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref> In an interview with ''[[The New York Times]]'', Noah likened Stewart to "a Jewish [[Yoda]]" and recounted advice Stewart gave him, saying, "The most amazing thing that Jon did was he didn’t give me a mandate. He didn’t say, 'You need to make my show.' He specifically said: 'Make your show. Make your best version of it.' I apply those teachings of Jon’s to everything that I’m doing."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/27/arts/television/trevor-noah-daily-show-jon-stewart.html|title=Trevor Noah on ‘The Daily Show’ and His ‘Jewish Yoda,’ Jon Stewart|work=The New York Times|first=Dave|last=Itzkoff|date=September 23, 2017|accessdate=November 6, 2017}}</ref>
Among comedians who say they were influenced by Noah are [[Michelle Wolf]] and [[Jordan Klepper]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/michelle-wolf-white-house-correspondents-dinner-host-comedian/|title=Comedian Michelle Wolf says it's "cowardly" for Trump to skip Correspondents' dinner|last=Wax|first=Jamie|date=April 28, 2018|accessdate=April 29, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324150849/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/michelle-wolf-white-house-correspondents-dinner-host-comedian/|archivedate=24 March 2016|deadurl=no|publisher=[[CBS News]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ewn.co.za/2017/09/26/trevor-noah-puts-on-executive-producer-hat-for-new-comedy-central-show|title=Trevor Noah Puts on Executive Producer Hat for New Show|website=[[Eyewitness News (South Africa)|Eyewitness News]]|date=December 26, 2017|accessdate=December 13, 2017|first=Nadia|last=Neophytou|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324150849/http://ewn.co.za/2017/09/26/trevor-noah-puts-on-executive-producer-hat-for-new-comedy-central-show|archivedate=24 March 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref> Noah's [[Coloured|mixed-race]] ancestry, his experiences growing up in [[Soweto]], and his observations about race and ethnicity are leading themes in his comedy.<ref>{{cite web |title=Why mixed-race comic was 'born a crime' |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/02/13/showbiz/trevor-noah-comedy/index.html |accessdate=12 October 2013 |publisher=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Trevor Noah interview – Comedy interviews |work=Time Out London |url=http://www.timeout.com/london/comedy/trevor-noah-interview |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>
== Personal life == Noah is a [[Polyglotism|polyglot]]; he speaks [[South African English|English]], [[Xhosa language|Xhosa]], [[Zulu language|Zulu]], [[Sotho language|Sotho]], [[Tswana language|Tswana]], [[Tsonga language|Tsonga]], [[Afrikaans]], and [[German language|German]].<ref name="nytimes33114" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghampost.co.uk/whats-on/comedy-gigs/south-african-comedian-trevor-noah-6319931|title=South African comedian Trevor Noah to play Birmingham’s Glee Club|author=Roz Laws|date=22 November 2013|work=birminghampost}}</ref>
In 1992 Noah's mother Patricia Nombuyiselo was married to Ngisaveni Abel Shingange, and they had two sons together, Andrew and Isaac. Trevor and his mother were both physically abused by Shingange, and the couple legally divorced in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/opinionista/2017-02-27-the-deadly-power-of-patriarchy/|title=The deadly power of patriarchy|author=Robyn Wolfson Vorster|publisher=Daily Maverick|date=2017-02-27|accessdate=2017-10-20}}</ref> In 2009, after she married Sfiso Khoza, Shingange shot her in the leg and through the back of the head; she survived as the bullet went through the base of her head, avoiding the spinal cord, brain, and all major nerves and blood vessels, then exiting with minor damage to her nostril. When Noah confronted him over the phone about the shooting, Shingange threatened his life, prompting Noah to leave [[Johannesburg]] for [[Los Angeles]].<ref name="channel24">{{cite news|last1=Sidimba|first1=Loyiso|title=Trevor Noah 'fled' to Hollywood|url=http://www.channel24.co.za/TopStories/Trevor-Noah-fled-to-Hollywood-20120311|accessdate=11 April 2015|work=Channel24.co.za|date=11 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title = Comedian’s stepdad shot mother {{!}} IOL|url = http://www.iol.co.za/news/comedians-stepdad-shot-mother-1248858|website = IOL|access-date = 2016-02-19}}</ref><ref name="citypress">{{cite news|title=Trevor Noah’s hell at home |url=http://www.citypress.co.za/entertainment/trevor-noahs-hell-at-home-20120303/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121214132227/http://www.citypress.co.za/entertainment/trevor-noahs-hell-at-home-20120303/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=14 December 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2015 |work=[[City Press (South Africa)|City Press]] |date=3 March 2012 |df= }} Noah, in an interview with Ezra Klein ([https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-ezra-klein-show/id1081584611?mt=2&i=373125945 podcast here]) said that the incident has been tabloidised and implied that his move to the United States was not caused by it.</ref> In 2011, Shingange was convicted of attempted murder, and sentenced the following year to three years of correctional supervision.<ref>{{cite news|title=Threats or No-ah threats, the tour is on |url=http://www.citypress.co.za/entertainment/threats-or-no-ah-threats-the-tour-is-on-20120804/ |accessdate=11 April 2015 |work=[[City Press (South Africa)|City Press]] |date=4 August 2012 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150417145640/http://www.citypress.co.za/entertainment/threats-or-no-ah-threats-the-tour-is-on-20120804/ |archivedate=17 April 2015 }}</ref> Noah stated that he hoped the attention surrounding the incident would raise awareness of the broader issue of [[domestic violence in South Africa]]: "For years my mother reached out to police for help with domestic abuse, and nothing was ever done. This is the norm in South Africa. Dockets went missing and cases never went to court."<ref name="channel24" />
Noah has described himself as being progressive and having a global perspective.<ref>{{cite news|last=Moore|first=Frazier|title='Daily Show' host Noah discusses his new gig |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/2154409ae5014f73908218a9569dcce6/ap-exclusive-daily-show-host-noah-discusses-his-new-gig|accessdate=31 March 2015|newspaper=[[Associated Press]]|date=31 March 2015}}</ref> However, he has clarified that he considers himself a "progressive person", but not a [[Progressivism in the United States|"political progressive"]] and prefers not to be categorized as being either [[right-wing politics|right]] or [[left-wing politics|left]] in the context of US partisanship.<ref>{{citation|title=The Daily Show’s Trevor Noah on being the new Jon Stewart: 'People have a right to not like me'|first=Tom|last=Teodorczuk|newspaper=The Independent|date=30 October 2015|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/features/the-daily-show-s-trevor-noah-on-being-the-new-jon-stewart-people-have-a-right-to-not-like-me-a6714676.html|accessdate=19 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=10 Ways 'The Daily Show With Trevor Noah' Aims to Move Beyond Jon Stewart|first=Eric|last=Kohn|website=Indiewire|date=27 September 2015|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/10-ways-the-daily-show-with-trevor-noah-aims-to-move-beyond-jon-stewart-20150927|accessdate=19 May 2016}}</ref>
Noah has been in a relationship with American model and singer [[Jordyn Taylor]] since 2015.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Parry|first1=Ryan|title=EXCLUSIVE: Trevor Noah strolls with new model girlfriend Jordyn Taylor, as her heartbreak after her fiancé was killed in a freak car accident is revealed|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3301032/Trevor-Noah-strolls-new-model-girlfriend-Jordyn-Taylor-heartbreak-fianc-killed-freak-car-accident-revealed.html|website=Daily Mail|accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref>
